articles.title: 125 million-year-old dinosaur with never before seen hollow spikes discovered in China
articles.summary: A 125-million-year-old dinosaur just rewrote what we thought we knew about prehistoric life. Scientists in China have uncovered an exceptionally preserved juvenile iguanodontian with fossilized skin so detailed that individual cells are still visible. Even more astonishing, the plant-eating dinosaur was covered in hollow, porcupine-like spikes—structures never before documented in any dinosaur.
articles.content:
For more than two centuries, paleontologists have studied a group of plant eating dinosaurs known as Iguanodontia. These dinosaurs were first identified in the early 1800s and are famous for their beaked mouths and strong hind legs. Now, that long established branch of the dinosaur family tree has gained a surprising new member. Researchers have identified a previously unknown species that carried a type of body covering never before documented in any dinosaur.

Scientists from the CNRS and collaborating institutions made the discovery in China, where they uncovered the fossilized remains of a remarkably well preserved young iguanodontian. What makes this specimen extraordinary is not just its skeleton, but its preserved skin. Soft tissues rarely survive for millions of years, yet in this case, even microscopic details endured.

Fossilized Skin and 125 Million Year Old Cells

Using advanced imaging techniques such as X ray scanning and high resolution histological analysis, which involves examining ultra thin slices of tissue under a microscope, the team was able to study the fossil at the cellular level. They found that individual skin cells had been preserved for approximately 125 million years. This level of detail allowed scientists to reconstruct the structure of unusual hollow spikes embedded in the skin.

These spikes, described as cutaneous because they originate in the skin, covered much of the dinosaur's body. Unlike horns or bony plates, they were not solid extensions of bone. Instead, they were hollow structures, a feature that has never previously been observed in dinosaurs. The newly identified species has been named Haolong dongi, honoring Dong Zhiming, a pioneering Chinese paleontologist who made major contributions to dinosaur research in China.

Porcupine Like Defense and Possible Additional Functions

Haolong dongi was a herbivore, meaning it fed on plants rather than other animals. During the Early Cretaceous period, when it lived, small carnivorous dinosaurs hunted in the same ecosystems. The hollow spikes may have served as a defensive adaptation, functioning in a way similar to the quills of a porcupine by discouraging predators from attacking.

However, defense may not have been their only purpose. Researchers suggest the spikes could also have helped regulate body temperature, a process known as thermoregulation. Structures that increase surface area can assist with releasing or conserving heat. Another possibility is that the spikes had a sensory role, helping the dinosaur detect movement or environmental changes around it.

A First of Its Kind Discovery

Until this fossil came to light, there was no evidence that dinosaurs possessed hollow skin based spines of this kind. Because the specimen is a juvenile, scientists cannot yet confirm whether adult individuals of the species retained the same structures as they matured. Further discoveries will be needed to answer that question.

The findings, published in Nature Ecology & Evolution on February 6, 2026, introduce an entirely new feature to the known diversity of dinosaur anatomy. This discovery not only adds a new species to the Iguanodontia group, but also reveals that dinosaur skin and body coverings were more varied and innovative than previously understood.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a 125-million-year-old dinosaur with unique hollow spikes preserved at cellular detail represents a significant scientific breakthrough. It advances paleontology by revealing new information about dinosaur anatomy and evolutionary adaptations, with broad implications for understanding prehistoric life. The detailed fossil and novel findings provide substantial context and impact beyond a niche audience.
articles.personality_title: New dinosaur with hollow spikes discovered in China, preserved in rare detail
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have studied plant-eating dinosaurs called Iguanodontia for over 200 years. These dinosaurs are known for their beaked mouths and strong legs. Until now, no one had found evidence of hollow spikes on any dinosaur’s skin.

**What happened** – Researchers in China found a 125-million-year-old fossil of a young iguanodontian dinosaur named Haolong dongi. Its skin was so well preserved that scientists could see individual cells using special X-ray scans and microscopes. The dinosaur’s body was covered with hollow, porcupine-like spikes, something never seen before in dinosaurs.

**Impact** – This discovery changes what we know about dinosaur skin and body coverings. The hollow spikes might have helped protect the dinosaur from predators, like a porcupine’s quills. They could also have helped control body temperature or sense the environment. Finding such detailed skin cells is very rare and gives scientists new clues about how dinosaurs lived.

**What’s next step** – Scientists want to find more fossils, especially adult Haolong dongi, to see if these spikes stayed as the dinosaur grew. They will also study how these spikes worked and if other dinosaurs had similar features. This could lead to new ideas about dinosaur evolution and diversity.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A 125-million-year-old dinosaur with unique hollow spikes and preserved skin cells reveals new details about how some dinosaurs protected and cared for themselves.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau dinosaure avec des pointes creuses découvert en Chine, conservé dans un détail rare
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient depuis plus de 200 ans des dinosaures herbivores appelés les Iguanodontia. Ces dinosaures sont connus pour leur bec et leurs pattes solides. Jusqu’à présent, personne n’avait trouvé de pointes creuses sur la peau d’un dinosaure.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs en Chine ont découvert un fossile d’un jeune dinosaure iguanodontien vieux de 125 millions d’années nommé Haolong dongi. Sa peau était si bien conservée que les scientifiques ont pu voir des cellules individuelles grâce à des scanners aux rayons X et des microscopes. Le corps du dinosaure était couvert de pointes creuses ressemblant à celles d’un porc-épic, une caractéristique jamais vue chez les dinosaures.

**Impact** – Cette découverte change ce que nous savons sur la peau et les couvertures corporelles des dinosaures. Ces pointes creuses auraient pu protéger le dinosaure des prédateurs, comme les piquants d’un porc-épic. Elles auraient aussi pu aider à réguler la température du corps ou à sentir l’environnement. Trouver des cellules de peau aussi détaillées est très rare et donne de nouvelles informations sur la vie des dinosaures.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent trouver d’autres fossiles, surtout d’adultes Haolong dongi, pour savoir si ces pointes restaient avec l’âge. Ils étudieront aussi comment ces pointes fonctionnaient et si d’autres dinosaures avaient des caractéristiques similaires. Cela pourrait ouvrir de nouvelles idées sur l’évolution et la diversité des dinosaures.

**Une phrase clé** – Un dinosaure vieux de 125 millions d’années avec des pointes creuses uniques et des cellules de peau conservées révèle de nouveaux détails sur la protection et les soins des dinosaures.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo dinosaurio con púas huecas descubierto en China, conservado con raro detalle
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han estudiado durante más de 200 años a los dinosaurios herbívoros llamados Iguanodontia. Estos dinosaurios son famosos por sus picos y patas fuertes. Hasta ahora, nadie había encontrado púas huecas en la piel de un dinosaurio.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores en China encontraron un fósil de 125 millones de años de un joven dinosaurio iguanodontiano llamado Haolong dongi. Su piel estaba tan bien conservada que los científicos pudieron ver células individuales con escáneres de rayos X y microscopios. El cuerpo del dinosaurio estaba cubierto de púas huecas parecidas a las de un puercoespín, algo nunca antes visto en dinosaurios.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento cambia lo que sabemos sobre la piel y las cubiertas corporales de los dinosaurios. Las púas huecas podrían haber protegido al dinosaurio de depredadores, como las púas de un puercoespín. También podrían haber ayudado a controlar la temperatura del cuerpo o a sentir el ambiente. Encontrar células de piel tan detalladas es muy raro y ofrece nuevas pistas sobre cómo vivían los dinosaurios.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos quieren encontrar más fósiles, especialmente de adultos Haolong dongi, para ver si estas púas seguían presentes al crecer. También estudiarán cómo funcionaban estas púas y si otros dinosaurios tenían características similares. Esto podría llevar a nuevas ideas sobre la evolución y diversidad de los dinosaurios.

**Una frase clave** – Un dinosaurio de 125 millones de años con púas huecas únicas y células de piel conservadas revela nuevos detalles sobre cómo algunos dinosaurios se protegían y cuidaban.
articles.image_prompt: A bright, modern laboratory with scientists working together, warm lighting, hopeful atmosphere, photorealistic
